ironic_python_agent/hardware_managers/cn.message: Nit: after disabling the embedded lldp agent in the CNA card

I can see that this would work but it overrides this exception with a different meaning (calling this manager has a side-effect which needs to happen before the actual collection)

The message describes what is happening, but it looks like it is never displayed or logged, instead in dispatch_to_all_managers and dispatch_to_managers we have this:

            except errors.IncompatibleHardwareMethodError:
                LOG.debug('HardwareManager {} does not support {}'
                          .format(manager, method))

If this logging did the following it would be clear what actually happened:
- included IncompatibleHardwareMethodError.details if it is not empty
- said something like "did not action" instead of "does not support"

My suggestion would be to break out GenericHardwareManager.collect_lldp_data into a standalone function, and have GenericHardwareManager.collect_lldp_data and IntelCnaHardwareManager.collect_lldp_data call it.

We can probably create a new exception with different logging? I'm quite against calling another hardware manager's method because they're supposed to be orthogonal and *in theory* the generic one may not be the one providing the actual collect_lldp_data.

A completely different approach would be to handle this logic in evaluate_harware_support and not override any methods at all.

Have you considered putting it in evaluate_hardware_support and then removing this method? e.g.; if _detect_cna_card(); log; disable lldp agent, return. This is not ideal if disabling the lldp agent is a task that takes long, but if it's nearly free you should just do it there.

yes, call collect_lldp_data can do things right for now too. But thinking about between generic manager and cna manager there has a "cna2" manager which need to disable another cna2-inner-lldp-service. Then things is broken again.

I have a long talk with dtantsur at this too. Basiclly, it's how the mechanism designed. Think about if between generic manager and cna manager has a new manager which would like to do something when collect_lldp_data too, call it directly will break this mechanism.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

ironic_python_agent/hardware_managers/cn.message: At some point I kind of wonder why we just don't call the method then. :\

Yes, we should log it. And i am concern about raise "IncompatibleHardwareMethodError" here too, strictly speaking, it's not "incompatible" here, it's some kind of not finished, should re-dispatch to manage chain. I am thinking about adding a Boolean return value for those collect_hardware_info functions, True means collected otherwise means should continue and re-dispatch. 

what do u think about this, @dtantsur.

I am agree with Dmitry. The first idea come to my head is adding something like "ReDispatchRequiredError" exception too. And the return value has been used. So, return boolean value is not possible here.

Great, this is what I was suggesting. It's a little bit of stretch but for hardware managers, the idea is you have to do any hardware initialization here -- e.g. loading drivers -- in order to know if you have the hardware inside you're trying to support.

Disabling the LLDP agent is *kinda* an initialization activity, so I think it fits.

+1

"false", it allows the use of driver-assisted-migration if support is available.

through the completion of the migration, including the switchover phase.
This should be "host", not "dest_host". Order it in the list of params.
I'd rephrase this as "The target pool to which the share should be migrated to, in format ``host@backend#pool``. E.g. ``ubuntu@generic1#GENERIC1``."

I'd rephrase it to: Forces the host-assisted mechanism to be used, thus using the Data Service to copy data across back ends. This parameter value defaults to ``False``. When set to ``True``, it skips the driver-assisted approach which would otherwise be attempted first. If this option is set to ``True``, all driver-assisted options must be set to ``False``.

I'd rephrase this to: Specifies whether migration should only be performed without disrupting clients during migration. For such, it is also expected that the export location does not change. When set to ``True`` and drivers are not capable of allowing the share to remain accessible through the two phases of the migration, migration will result in an error status. As of Ocata release, host-assisted migration cannot provide this capability.

I'd rephrase to: Specifies whether migration should enforce the preservation of all file system metadata. When set to ``True`` and drivers are not capable of ensuring preservation of file system metadata, migration will result in an error status. As of Ocata release, host-assisted migration cannot provide any guarantees of preserving file system metadata.

I'd rephrase to: Specifies whether migration should enforce the preservation of all existing snapshots at the destination. When set to ``True`` and drivers are not capable of migrating the snapshots, migration will result in an error status. As of Ocata release, host-assisted migration cannot provide this capability.
We don't pass this param in any migration API request body, remove this

I'd rephrase to: Specifies whether migration should only be performed if the share can remain writable. When this behavior is set to ``True`` and drivers are not capable of allowing the share to remain writable, migration will result in an error status. If drivers are not capable of performing a nondisruptive migration, manila will ensure that the share will remain writable through the data copy phase of migration. However, during the switchover phase the share will be re-exported at the destination, causing the share to be rendered inaccessible for the duration of this phase. As of Ocata release, host-assisted migration cannot provide this capability.

I'd split this comparison with bullets and talk about the different methods so it's clear to the reader the main differences. Something like:

- ``Driver-assisted migration``: This mechanism is intended to make use of driver optimizations to migrate shares between pools of the same storage vendor. This mechanism allows migrating shares nondisruptively while the source remains writable, preserving all filesystem metadata and snapshots. The migration workload is performed in the storage back end.
- ``Host-assisted migration``: This mechanism is intended to migrate shares in an agnostic manner between two different pools, regardless of storage vendor. The implementation for this mechanism does not offer the same properties found in driver-assisted migration. In host-assisted migration, the source remains readable, snapshots must be deleted prior to starting the migration, filesystem metadata may be lost, and the clients will get disconnected by the end of migration. The migration workload is performed by the Data Service, which is a dedicated manila service for intensive data operations.

I believe this is a feature, at least as this is worded.

If the note says (which I think it likely should say based upon the code) that it fixes support for bios setting application on redfish machines where an apply time MUST be defined, such on on dell iDRACs.

It appears the library knows when this is the case and raises that to the library user/caller. At which point the caller CAN take the appropriate option. The release note words it as if the client of the system is making a decision of when to set the apply time, and by client in the release note context, I'm meaning the person using/operating ironic.

You are correct that this change is a bug fix.

I reworded the note as you suggested.

'client' was referring to the software client interacting with the Redfish Service, which is the 'redfish' driver and sushy package. Since that word is ambiguous, it is no longer used.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
If you put in a very large playbook, would it output the entire playbook here?

I intentionally did not want to be so spammy with these error messages.  We do quote some code when there's a Zuul config error because we can extract the relevant part, but that's not the case here, where the error is something that we don't understand.

Maybe we could include +/- 5 raw lines.

However, I think a better approach would be to rely on inline comments.  Both Gerrit and Github are able to leave line comments for Zuul config errors.  Maybe we can update ConfigItem errors to include file information so that they can leave file comments.

I agree a better approach is to get inline comments, but it seems to me to a large refactor to get these values in context; I can't immediately see how to keep the association since this is all working on bits of config that has been parsed and is now a regular dict/list etc.

The latest revision takes the approach of trimming the lines as suggested, which might be a compromise position.

masakari/conf/engine.py.message:
IMO, we can override init_host method and process notifications in NEW/ERROR statuses so that when masakari-engine is restarted, it will process notifications in NEW/ERROR statuses. I think with this implementation, there will be no need to add a new periodic task.

Also, we need to think what should be the default value of config options "process_unfinished_notifications_interval" and "retry_notification_new_status_interval". 

Should process_unfinished_notifications_interval < retry_notification_new_status_interval?

That’s one choice. But there still is one risk.  In the real condition, if one notification has been in NEW status for long time, it is not allowed to be processed again. Only notifitions is not older than 'retry_notification_new_status_interval' will be processed again. If it is older, it will remains all times.
To the notifications in 'ERROR' status, it will be update to 'FAILED' status. It's not a problem.
To the notifications in 'RUNNIG' status, there is no method to check if it is in processing. It will remain all times.
I think they are both necessary, to check expired notifications and process unfinished notifications.

Why one notification woud be in NEW status for long time, it is another feature I will import in V. In short, due to limit and circuit breaker when large scale hosts failure， not all notifications will be process at once, so there will be some notifications remain in NEW status for long time.
To notification in RUNNIG status, if there is one masakari-engine, it can be processed again when masakari-engine restarted again. but if there are more than two masakari-engine, how do we verify it is in processing or terminated abruptly?

> if one notification has been in NEW status for long time,  it is not allowed to be processed again
I'm trying to understand in what circumstances, the notifications in NEW status will not be processed?
Is it because, masakari-engine is down or rabbitMQ is down?

If a notification is set to "RUNNING" status, the next transition would be from RUNNING->(FINISHED or IGNORED or ERROR). Before setting it to either of these status, if the masakari-engine process is terminated  abruptly, then when it will be restarted again, we can process notifications which are in NEW, RUNNING, or ERROR statuses in the init_host method.

It's not supported in the current design. If you run two masakari-engine services at the same time on two different hosts, then it would pickup same notifications and process it inside periodic task which could lead to more severe problems.

It's improper understanding. Like other project, the masakari-engine process the notification by rpc called from masakari-api. The rpc called will ensure only one masakari-engine will continously process the notification. 
Even if the rpc call was blocked, the status of the notification acts like a DB lock. Only one masakari-engine can occupy the 'NEW'notification and update the status to 'RUNNING', so other masakari-engine won't process the 'RUNNING' notification again.

This is tested in my env, 3 masakari-api/engine on 3 control nodes.

I generally observed behaviour reported by suzhengwei's so I agree with suzhengwei on that.

But I guess we could still mix the two ideas and check on init while considering the timeout, hmm? I guess we need a bit better design so that engines actually coordinate this between themselves (who's working on which notification). Due to the simple nature of this resource (the notification) we could probably get away without any heavy coordination via tooz and instead keep the necessary information in the database (as handling uniqueness is done by the message queue already).

zuul/driver/mqtt/mqttreporter.py.message: I think it still needs to be disambiguated as the owner username, since Gerrit can supply other related objects with usernames in its events too (author, uploader, submitter). This string is a reasonably unique representation of the "owner" in Gerrit, and the other information such as display name or E-mail address can be looked up anonymously through the Gerrit API if it's needed. If we wanted to get more granular than just usernames for these we would need to extend the data structure, but the other connection drivers are similarly just using various username strings as well at the moment.
